continents.name: Africa
continents.stats: Over 50% of the world's out-of-school children live in Africa.
continents.challenges: Conflict, poverty, and lack of infrastructure pose significant challenges to implementing children's rights.
continents.charter: The African Charter on the Rights and Welfare of the Child.

countries.name: Nigeria
countries.info: Nigeria has the largest number of out-of-school children in the world (estimated at around 10.5 million).

countries.name: South Africa
countries.info: South Africa has strong constitutional protections for children but faces challenges of inequality and violence.

continents.name: Asia
continents.stats: Asia is home to the largest number of child laborers in the world.
continents.challenges: Trafficking, child marriage, and disparities in education access between urban and rural areas are major concerns.
continents.charter: Many countries have national plans, but regional coordination is growing through bodies like ASEAN.

countries.name: India
countries.info: India's 'Child Labour (Prohibition and Regulation) Act' was amended in 2016 to strengthen protections against child labor.

countries.name: China
countries.info: China has made significant strides in education, achieving near-universal primary school attendance.

continents.name: Europe
continents.stats: Europe has some of the strongest legal protections for children globally.
continents.challenges: Protecting migrant and refugee children, and combating online exploitation are key priorities.
continents.charter: The Council of Europe Strategy for the Rights of the Child.

countries.name: United Kingdom
countries.info: The UK has an independent Children's Commissioner to champion the rights of children.

countries.name: Germany
countries.info: Germany has robust social support systems but faces challenges in integrating refugee children into the education system.

continents.name: North America
continents.stats: Issues of child poverty and access to mental health services are significant.
continents.challenges: Ensuring equal opportunities for all children, regardless of their background, and addressing the digital divide.
continents.charter: National laws and policies are the primary mechanisms, with active participation in UN conventions.

countries.name: USA
countries.info: The United States is the only UN member state that has not ratified the Convention on the Rights of the Child.

countries.name: Canada
countries.info: Canada has a strong focus on reconciliation with Indigenous peoples, including addressing the historical impact on children's rights.

continents.name: South America
continents.stats: Significant progress has been made in increasing primary school enrollment.
continents.challenges: Inequality, violence against children, and the impact of environmental issues on indigenous communities.
continents.charter: The Organization of American States (OAS) works to promote and protect human rights in the region.

countries.name: Brazil
countries.info: Brazil's 'Statute of the Child and Adolescent' is a comprehensive legal framework for protecting children's rights.

continents.name: Oceania
continents.stats: Climate change poses a direct threat to the rights of children living on low-lying islands.
continents.challenges: Providing quality education and healthcare to remote and indigenous populations.
continents.charter: Dominated by national-level frameworks in Australia and New Zealand, with regional cooperation on child protection.

countries.name: Australia
countries.info: Australia faces challenges in addressing the disparities in health and education outcomes for Indigenous children.
